title: US: 988 Suicide & Crisis Lifeline (call/text/chat)
content: If you are in the United States and in crisis, call or text 988 or use the online chat at the 988 Lifeline website for 24/7 support from trained counselors. If you are in immediate danger call 911.

title: US: Crisis Text Line (TEXT HOME to 741741)
content: Text HOME to 741741 in the United States to connect with a trained volunteer Crisis Counselor 24/7. This service is confidential and free.

title: International Helpline Directory (Befrienders)
content: For local crisis helplines worldwide, use the Befrienders / IASP directory to find a country-specific center that provides emotional support and listening services.

title: When to Call Emergency Services
content: Call local emergency services (e.g., 911 in the US, local emergency number elsewhere) if there is an immediate threat to life, if the person has intent and means to harm themselves, or if they are medically unstable.

title: Brief Safety Plan Template (1–2 minutes)
content: Quick plan: 1) Recognize warning signs; 2) Use coping strategies (breathing, grounding); 3) Contact supportive person; 4) Remove immediate means if possible; 5) Call crisis line or emergency services if danger persists.

title: Identifying Warning Signs
content: Warning signs can include talk of hopelessness, giving away belongings, sudden withdrawal, increased substance use, or explicit talk of suicide. Early recognition allows for earlier help.

title: Immediate De-escalation Script (3 lines)
content: Say: 'I’m really sorry you’re feeling this. I want to help — are you safe right now? If you’re able, take one slow breath with me.' Use gentle tone and short sentences.

title: How to Ask About Suicidal Thoughts
content: Use direct, nonjudgmental questions: 'Are you thinking about killing yourself?' 'Do you have a plan or means?' Asking openly helps assess risk and doesn’t increase risk.

title: SAMHSA National Helpline & 988 Information (US)
content: SAMHSA lists national helplines and details about 988; it’s a useful resource for clinicians and users seeking treatment and crisis info.

title: Immediate Safety Steps for Others
content: If someone tells you they’re thinking of harming themselves: stay with them (if safe), remove immediate means (if possible), contact emergency services or crisis line, and stay connected until help arrives.

title: Ask-Help-Plan Script for Helpers
content: Ask: 'Are you safe now?' Help: 'Can I call someone for you or stay on the line?' Plan: 'If things worsen, we will call emergency services together.' Use to structure immediate help.

title: International Association for Suicide Prevention Links
content: IASP aggregates crisis center information and research; use their site to find international referral options.

title: Self-Harm vs Suicidal Intent
content: Self-harm (non-suicidal) and suicidal behavior differ in intent. Assess intention directly and ask about plans/means. Both behaviors need compassion and professional evaluation.

title: Short Grounding for Crisis Moments
content: Prompt: 'Name 3 colors you see, take three slow breaths, and press your feet into the floor.' Repeat until the person reports a small drop in distress.

title: How Chatbots Should Handle Crisis Language
content: When a user expresses self-harm or suicidal intent: 1) acknowledge and validate, 2) ask direct questions about safety, 3) provide crisis resources, 4) escalate to human support per policy and local law. Avoid judgmental language.

title: When To Suggest Emergency Care
content: Suggest emergency care when there is imminent danger, active suicidal intent with plan/means, severe self-harm, or psychosis. Encourage calling local emergency services immediately.

title: Safety Planning Questions (short)
content: Ask user: 'What are your warning signs? What calms you? Who can you call? What steps will you take if urges increase?' Fill answers into a simple plan to save or send.

title: De-escalation Do's and Don'ts
content: Do: stay calm, validate feelings, ask direct questions. Don’t: minimize feelings, argue, or use ultimatums. Use short sentences and slow tone.

title: Local Emergency Number Prompt Template
content: Template for the bot: 'If you’re in immediate danger where you are, please call your local emergency number (for example, 911 in the United States) or go to the nearest emergency department.'

title: Removing Means — Practical Advice
content: Encourage removing or securing means (medication, weapons) where possible and safe. Offer to help call someone or a helpline to assist in making a plan.

title: Crisis Lines for Specific Groups (referral guidance)
content: When applicable, refer to specialized services (e.g., LGBTQ+ crisis organizations, veterans' lines, youth services). Use local directories and national orgs for targeted support.

title: Immediate Coping Script (1–2 minutes)
content: Script: 'Right now, let’s try one slow breath. I’ll stay with you while you breathe. After three breaths, tell me one small thing you can see in the room.' Repeat and then offer next steps.

title: Confidentiality Limits — What to Tell Users
content: Inform users that if there is imminent risk of harm to self/others, confidentiality may be limited for safety and emergency services may be contacted. Encourage voluntary help-seeking first.

title: How to Find Local Mental Health Services
content: Use national health portals (e.g., NHS in the UK) or local directories; Befrienders provides international contact points. Encourage contacting a GP or local mental-health team for assessment.

title: Brief Follow-Up Template After Crisis Message
content: Prompt: 'I’m glad you reached out. Are you okay to tell me what helped since we last spoke? If not, would you like me to list crisis numbers or help make a plan?' This re-engages and checks safety.

title: How to Support Someone After a Crisis
content: Offer presence and listening, help connect them with professional care, and support the creation or updating of a safety plan. Encourage follow-up contact and remove stigma about seeking help.

title: Text/Chat Options vs Call Options
content: Some people prefer text or chat (e.g., Crisis Text Line or online 988 chat). Offer both options and respect the user's communication preference.
source: 988 Lifeline and Crisis Text Line info

title: If User Refuses Help — Safety Script
content: Say: 'I hear you. I’m worried and want to make sure you’re safe. Would you let me share a few options that others have found helpful?' Offer choices gently and avoid pressure.

title: Short-Term Coping Options to Suggest
content: Offer grounding, breathing, contact a trusted person, go to a public place, or call a crisis line. Pair each suggestion with a brief step so users can act immediately.

title: Where Providers Can Find Training
content: Providers seeking crisis-intervention training can consult SAMHSA, IASP materials, and local health authorities for evidence-based training and toolkits.

title: How Bot Should Escalate to Human Clinician
content: If user indicates imminent danger or intent, bot should: 1) provide crisis resources, 2) ask permission to share contact, 3) if consented or if mandated by policy, notify on-call clinician with timestamped transcript and safety info.

title: Why Safety Plans Work
content: Safety plans specify personalized coping strategies and contacts, which reduce immediate risk by making help steps clear and actionable during high distress.

title: Short Supporter-Activation Script
content: Ask: 'Who can you call right now? Would you like me to draft a quick message you could send to them asking for help?' Offer to format a short text to reduce activation friction.

title: Dealing With Aftershocks (post-crisis care)
content: After a crisis, people often feel drained or raw. Encourage rest, follow-up with a professional, avoid major decisions, and use the safety plan to restore stability.

title: Quick Links: 988 / Crisis Text / Befrienders
content: Key verified resources: 988 Lifeline (US) — 988lifeline.org; Crisis Text Line — crisistextline.org (Text HOME to 741741); Befrienders international directory — befrienders.org.
